result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: a large CO evolution rate outperforms most of previously reported carbon-based photocatalysts (Table S1) and two typical photocatalysts, g-C 3 N 4 (16.3 mol h -1 g -1 ) and P25 (17 mol h -1 g -1 ) under comparable condition.No product can be detected in the absence of catalyst (Fig. 2a), demonstrating that the catalyst is indispensable for solar-driven CO 2 conversion.In addition, no detectable products are observed when the reaction system is manipulated in the dark condition (Fig. 2a), suggesting the

investigation shows that the incorporation of NH 2group can improve its charge density and converge more electrons to adsorb CO 2 molecules.In situ Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy spectra disclose that the COOH radical is the main intermediate.The findings reveal the correlation between surface NH 2 -group and photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance and can be extended to other sustainable metal-free based catalysts for solar-driven CO 2 reduction.

(Fig. 2a), suggesting the photocatalytic nature of CO 2 reduction.No CO is generated when we use helium (He) to replace CO 2 under otherwise identical conditions, indicating the generated CO is derived from visible light photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.To provide direct proof for CO product generated from the CO 2 , 13 C-labeled isotopic experiment was carried out.As shown in Fig. 2b, gas chromatographymass spectrometer (GC-MS) results reveal that 13 CO is detected when using 13 CO 2 as substrate, further

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

samples before evaluating their visible-light-driven CO 2 reduction properties.Both TRP and TRP-NH 2 samples manifest strong photoabsorption ability ranging from UV to visible light region, and their bandgaps (Figure S2-b) can be calculated to be 1.08 and 1.2 eV, respectively, based on the UV-vis DRS results.Mott-Schottky plots (Figure S2-c) of these two samples are estimated to be -0.54 and -0.63 V (vs AgAgCl electrode), respectively.Thus, their derived flat band potentials are around -0.34 and -0.43 V

and sacrifice reagent.As shown in Fig. 2a, the predominant reaction product is CO accompanied by a trace amount of methane (not show).The TRP sample exhibits CO 2 -to-CO transformation rate of 488.4 mol h -1 g -1 .Once the TRP sample is functionalized with NH 2group, the CO evolution activity is significantly improved, and the TRP-NH 2 (c) catalyst yields the highest CO evolution rate of 1165.3 mol h -1 g -1 , roughly 2.4 and 70.1 times than those of TRP and g-C 3 N 4 samples.Such a large CO evolution rate
